name: OpenStax Microbiology Textbook - Chapter 14
description: Multiple-choice questions from the 'Multiple Choice' section of Chapter 14 of the OpenStax Microbiology textbook.
subject: Microbiology

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: A scientist discovers that a soil bacterium he has been studying produces an antimicrobial that kills gram-negative bacteria. She isolates and purifies the antimicrobial compound, then chemically converts a chemical side chain to a hydroxyl group. When she tests the antimicrobial properties of this new version, she finds that this antimicrobial drug can now also kill gram-positive bacteria. The new antimicrobial drug with broad-spectrum activity is considered to be which of the following?
questions.explanation: A chemically modified derivative of a natural antibiotic is a semisynthetic antimicrobial.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following antimicrobial drugs is synthetic?
questions.explanation: Sulfanilamide is a synthetic antimicrobial drug. Penicillin, actinomycin, and neomycin are all natural antibiotics.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following combinations would most likely contribute to the development of a superinfection?
questions.explanation: Long-term use of broad-spectrum antimicrobials can lead to the development of superinfections by killing off a wide range of the normal microbiota.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following routes of administration would be appropriate and convenient for home administration of an antimicrobial to treat a systemic infection?
questions.explanation: Oral administration is typically the most convenient route for home administration of an antimicrobial for a systemic infection.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which clinical situation would be appropriate for treatment with a narrow-spectrum antimicrobial drug?
options: treatment of a polymicrobic mixed infection in the intestine
prophylaxis against infection after a surgical procedure
treatment of strep throat caused by culture identified Streptococcus pyogenes
empiric therapy of pneumonia while waiting for culture results
questions.explanation: A narrow-spectrum antimicrobial is appropriate when the causative pathogen has been identified, such as in the case of strep throat caused by S. pyogenes.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following terms refers to the ability of an antimicrobial drug to harm the target microbe without harming the host?
questions.explanation: Selective toxicity is the ability of an antimicrobial drug to harm the target microbe without harming the host.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of β-lactam antimicrobial?
questions.explanation: Glycopeptides are not β-lactam antimicrobials. Penicillins, cephalosporins, and monobactams are all types of β-lactam antimicrobials.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following does not bind to the 50S ribosomal subunit?
questions.explanation: Tetracyclines bind to the 30S ribosomal subunit, while lincosamides, macrolides, and chloramphenicol bind to the 50S ribosomal subunit.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following antimicrobials inhibits the activity of DNA gyrase?
questions.explanation: Nalidixic acid is a quinolone that inhibits the activity of DNA gyrase.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following is not an appropriate target for antifungal drugs?
questions.explanation: Cholesterol is found in human cell membranes, not fungal cell membranes, so it is not an appropriate target for antifungal drugs. Ergosterol, chitin, and β(1→3) glucan are all appropriate targets.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following drug classes specifically inhibits neuronal transmission in helminths?
questions.explanation: Avermectins are a class of drugs that specifically inhibit neuronal transmission in helminths.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following is a nucleoside analog commonly used as a reverse transcriptase inhibitor in the treatment of HIV?
questions.explanation: Azidothymidine (AZT) is a nucleoside analog and reverse transcriptase inhibitor used to treat HIV.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following is an antimalarial drug that is thought to increase ROS levels in target cells?
questions.explanation: Artemisinin is an antimalarial drug that is thought to increase reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels in target cells.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following resistance mechanisms describes the function of β-lactamase?
questions.explanation: β-lactamase is an enzyme that inactivates β-lactam antibiotics, which is a form of drug inactivation.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following resistance mechanisms is commonly effective against a wide range of antimicrobials in multiple classes?
questions.explanation: Efflux pumps can be effective against a wide range of antimicrobials by pumping them out of the cell.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following resistance mechanisms is the most nonspecific to a particular class of antimicrobials?
questions.explanation: Efflux pumps are often nonspecific and can pump out a wide variety of antimicrobial drugs.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following types of drug-resistant bacteria do not typically persist in individuals as a member of their intestinal microbiota?
questions.explanation: MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) is typically found on the skin and in the nose, not as a persistent member of the intestinal microbiota.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: In the Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion test, the _______ of the zone of inhibition is measured and used for interpretation.
questions.explanation: In the Kirby-Bauer test, the diameter of the zone of inhibition is measured to determine the susceptibility of a microbe to an antimicrobial drug.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following techniques cannot be used to determine the minimum inhibitory concentration of an antimicrobial drug against a particular microbe?
questions.explanation: The Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion test can determine susceptibility but not the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC). The Etest, microbroth dilution test, and macrobroth dilution test can all determine the MIC.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: The utility of an antibiogram is that it shows antimicrobial susceptibility trends
questions.explanation: An antibiogram provides information about antimicrobial susceptibility trends in a localized population, such as within a hospital or community.

questions.subject: Microbiology
questions.question: Which of the following has yielded compounds with the most antimicrobial activity?
questions.explanation: Soil has been the source of many important antimicrobial compounds, largely due to the vast diversity of microorganisms it contains.
